titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Marilyn Hacker Papers
titlestmt.author: Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 05:50

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 432, Uncat MSS 602.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing in 2013. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two groupings: May 2002 Acquisition, and January 2003 Acquisition.

bioghist.head: Marilyn Hacker (1942-)
bioghist.p: Marilyn Hacker, American poet and editor, was born in New York City in 1942 and attended New York University, receiving a B.A. in Romance Languages in 1964. Hacker's first collection of poems, Presentation Piece (New York: Viking Press, 1974), was the recipient of the National Book Award. Her other collections include Names (W. W. Norton, 2009), Desesperanto: Poems 1999-2002 (2005); First Cities: Collected Early Poems 1960-1979 (2003); and Squares and Courtyards (2000). In addition to writing poetry, Hacker was the editor of the Kenyon Review from 1990 to 1994, and has translated the work of many European poets into English.
Hacker was married to science fiction writer Samuel Delany from 1961 to 1974 and has one daughter. She lives in New York City and Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, writings, personal papers, photographs, audiovisual material, and printed material that document the life and work of American author, editor, critic, and translator Marilyn Hacker. Hacker's writings are documented by typescript drafts, proofs, and associated material, including correspondence with fellow authors and publishers. Kenyon Review materials document Hacker's tenure as editor of the journal, including controversy surrounding her dismissal. The Marilyn Hacker Papers are of interest for their documentation of twentieth-century American poetry and literary life generally, as well as the gay and lesbian liberation movements of the 1970s and after.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 18-22 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Marilyn Hacker Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Marilyn Hacker on the Eugene G. O'Neill Memorial Fund, 2002-2003.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence. II. Writings. III. Personal Papers. IV. Photographs and Audiovisual Material. V. Printed Material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under four headings: Alphabetical, Chronological, Kenyon Review, and Unsorted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence filed under this heading consists of incoming professional and personal correspondence from publishers, editors, academics, writers, artists, family and friends, documenting Hacker's activities as a writer, teacher, editor, and critic. Correspondents include Samuel R. Delany, Hayden Carruth, Tom Disch, and Joanna Russ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material filed under this heading consists of correspondence and other papers related to Hacker's work at the Kenyon Review and Kenyon College.

did.unittitle: Letters of outrage at Marilyn Hacker's dismissal
Letters of support for the Kenyon Review

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under two headings: Writings of Marilyn Hacker; Writings of Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings consist of drafts (autograph manuscript and typescript, some corrected) of Hacker's poetry and essays (including translations), as well as notes and other related material. Unless otherwise noted, titles refer to poems or compilations of poems. Some files contain paste-ups, mechanicals, proofs and associated material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Largely arranged alphabetically by title or keyword; unsorted writings are filed at the end of the listing.

did.unittitle: Going back to the river , typescript
Love, death and the changing of the seasons , typescript

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contains drafts, typescripts, mechanicals, page proofs

did.unittitle: "The Trees win every time, reading Julia Randall," typescripts and printed version (photocopy)

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes set copy, typescripts, paste-ups, and page proofs

did.unittitle: Materials related to poetry in translation

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by author. Works of unidentified authors are filed at the end of the subseries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings of Others consist of manuscripts (largely typescripts) sent to Marilyn Hacker by authors. Some manuscripts include cover letters that provide evidence of Hacker's relationships with the authors, or the author's reason for sending the manuscript to Hacker for review.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Marilyn Hacker's, medical, financial and publishing records, address and appointment books, and a scrapbook.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under five headings: Photographs; Reel-to-Reel Audiotapes; Sound Discs; Audio Cassettes; and Video Cassettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs consist of prints, negatives, and slides, of Marilyn Hacker, and her family members, friends, and associates. Most of the photographs are informal snapshots, but several formal portraits of Hacker are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A written postcard, included with this audiocassette, reads: M- These are the preliminary mixes, but I think they're 99% what we decided to keep on the master. You said you'd like to hear the "[Fovah]" poem with music. I hope you enjoy it! Love, M.
